results.title: Emulation of Decisive Battles of the American Civil War Vol 1 for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Decisive Battles of the American Civil War, Vol. 1 lets you take the place of commanding generals in six battles of the American Civil War: first Bull Run, Shiloh, second Bull Run, Antietam, Fredericksburg, and Chancellorsville. In that role, players not only issue orders but take actions such as sleeping and determining their level of personal participation in the battle. The result is a fast-paced simulation (one hour per turn) of important moments in Civil War history. Victory is determined by a tally of casualties and controlled objectives. Two players may face-off in hot-seat mode, or a single player may face the computer or just observe the computer controlling both sides.

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1988 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Classic Cave Adventure  for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Classic Cave Adventure is a single player text adventure set in a cave. Text commands allow the player to move and interact with environment. Commands are rigid and set to actions like “Move”

Original game created for Commodore 64 by Matthew Hall and released into the public domain circa 1985. More info on Matt Hall’s games can be found at: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/bedroom-coders-matthew-hall-15-commodore-64-games-rescued-from-decaying-cassettes/

results.title: Emulation of Castle of Terror for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
A single-player adventure game where the player is given a quest by an old man at the local tavern to rescue his daughter from the clutches of the local Count (a vampire), who resides in the nearby castle. Throughout the game, the player gathers items, which can then be manipulated to solve various puzzles.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, Published in 1984 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Emulation of Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific for Commodore 64 emulation
results.brief_description:
Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific is a war simulation (wargame). In the game the player takes on the role of the task force commander in the pacific theater during World War II. In the six simulated conflicts the player can play as both the U.S. and the Japanese Empire. Included scenarios are Pearl Harbor, Coral Sea, Midway, Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz and Philippine Sea. The game is played on a 72x84 hexagonal grid. The player can gives orders to the individual units and squadrons, which include naval vessels and land based aircraft. The computer then simulates how they perform their actions. The game is quasi real-time, meaning that the game can be paused at any given moment at which time the player can give orders to the units. All interaction with the game is through a menu interface. Orders that can be given to units include strike, escort, transport, support, refuel and more complex maneuvers such as strike routines.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/goldfields/

Last accessed: 6/05/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1984 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Battles in Normandy 1944 for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Battles in Normandy is a turn-based wargame employing hex grids, built on the Battlefront engine. It deals with the 1944 Allied landing in German-occupied Normandy during the Second World War. The eight scenarios included are: Omaha, Utah, Sword, Cherbourg, Carentan, Villers-Bocage, Goodwood and Epsom. As with Battlefront the command scale is at the corps level. The battle system incorporates the factors of adverse weather and terrain, supply, experience and morale. A complete range of unit types is provided. Victory depends on seizing the key locations within the turn limit.

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1987 by Strategic Studies Group
results.title_for_label: Battles in Normandy 1944 [computer game] for Commodore 64 [harvested game emulation file]
results.description:
Battles in Normandy is a turn-based wargame employing hex grids, built on the Battlefront engine. It deals with the 1944 Allied landing in German-occupied Normandy during the Second World War. The eight scenarios included are: Omaha, Utah, Sword, Cherbourg, Carentan, Villers-Bocage, Goodwood and Epsom. As with Battlefront the command scale is at the corps level. The battle system incorporates the factors of adverse weather and terrain, supply, experience and morale. A complete range of unit types is provided. Victory depends on seizing the key locations within the turn limit.

results.title: Emulation of Battlefront Corps Level Command WWII for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Battlefront: Corps Level Command in World War II is a turn-based strategy/war simulation game. A recreation of the land battles of World War II, it offers the following scenarios: Crete (1941), Stalingrad (1942), Saipan (1944) and Bastogne (1944-5). It includes a complete scenario editor, which is unusual in that it enables creation of new terrain types, and can even be invoked mid-game. This is one of the first series of games in which software micromanaged the actions of the individual units, such as battalions or artillery assets.

The Battlefront game system, released in 1986 for the Apple II and the Commodore 64, was designed for land battles of the Second World War. It simulated the challenges of real command, including those of managing supply and troop fatigue. In response to player requests and fresh design enhancements, SSG released new iterations of their systems adding additional features. Battlefront update Battle of Normandy (1987) added climate types, so scenarios could be created for regions beyond Europe.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/battlefront-battlefront-corps-level-command-in-world-war-ii/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1986 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Bad Street Brawler for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Originally released as Bop’n Rumble, and known as Street Hassle in Australia. This single-player beat-‘em-up style game lets players control Duke Davis, who goes from stage to stage beating up gangsters that get in his way, dressed in a yellow tank top, sunglasses, and yellow pants. He is described as a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist.

Original game developed by Beam Software Pty., Ltd. for Commodore 64. Published in 1987 by Mindscape Inc.

results.title: Emulation of Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum ZX 48k
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021
